intro: Lamourouxia dependens var. apiculata, commonly known as the Apiculate Hairy Bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to parts of southern Europe and western Asia. It is characterized by its hairy, glandular stems and leaves, which contribute to its distinctive appearance. The plant produces small, bell-shaped flowers that are typically blue or purple in color, often with a white or yellow throat. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland or meadow habitats. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
